print_settings.Notes:: No rafts, brim or support is needed.

description.text:
This is a cable holder, designed by me in OpenSCAD to hold multiple cables close together.
With a piece of double sided adhesive tape, this cable holder can be attached to any flat surface. Most often this will be the plinth near the floor, but it can just as easily be the back of your TV-set or Personale Computer.

This cable holder is available in several sizes, depending on the type and amount of cables you need to keep together.
The narrow holder has a base width of 7 mm and is available in 25 mm and 30 mm length and are sufficient to hold 3 to 5 PC cables like UTP cabling, telephone wiring, keyboard/mouse-cables.
The wider 8 mm model is available in 25 mm, 30 mm and 35 mm length and will hold power cables.

Print in any material with sufficient infill for optimal strength. Standard PLA will do just fine, but PETG and ABS are also good options.

description.text:
This part is to allow you to take the Anet A8 rear mount sensor and move it to the front when you convert to the E3d hotend. It allows the user to fine tune the sensor height adjustment. It is meant to be used with the customizable e3d mount. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577

I adapted the front e3d plate with the adjustable mount I found and will link later.

I am currently using skynet on my A8 and I'm working on fine tuning the design and the skynet setup.

For installation, I used hot glue to mount the sensor to the plate. It also used a 45mm m3 screw and m3 nut. for the spring, you can rob the spring from one of your clicky pens from the junk drawer.

This part has made adjustment of the hot end/bed gap so much easier.

I have been searching for the best way to use my desktop in my living room while still being able to watch TV. Mounting a second TV was pretty much our of the question, so I looked to a portable monitor. I created a mount that can slide on to the Razer Turret and mount the AOC USB 3.0 Monitor. I also tried with the Acer USB-C monitor but I couldn't get it to work with my laptop. This mount is pretty universal, all you have to do is adjust the size of the cut out on the top.

I'm still working on the angle but you can see the initial design and implementation. It pretty much solved my issue of using my desktop on my couch.

title: Tracer Pulse Bomb Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Daughter and I had an idea, so this is what we come up with. Thanks to mattkim95 for the model.
Basically it only has the single 608 bearing in the middle. Printing at 80% doesn't give it much extra weight (doubt 100% would either) but it was more the looks was what I was going for.
My daughter has a lot of friends that love playing Overwatch so figured this might be something neat they could have in their collection.
The parts are seperated by color, gray, black and the yellow pieces so no real painting needed. Just print, clean and glue the yellow bits on.
Supports are unfortunately needed for the top bearing cap. I couldn't figure out a cleaner way to design it. At least that part is hidden so you might need to do some sanding/cutting to clean it up a little bit.

Update
I added 3 new models all with _Lg. These are a larger version of the spinner. It requires 6x 1/4" bearings/slingshot ammo as weight.

Instruction for the Large Spinner
Watch the print of the body. If you can, sift through the layers and find the spot where the 6 holes are about to be covered (around layer 37 or 38). Pause the print, drop a small drop of super glue in there and drop a 1/4" bearing (1/4" slingshot ammo) in each hold. Not to much lol. The superglue will help keep it in place albeit not permanently but it's better than nothing. The print will then start to cover the hole and it will have at least 2 weights on each tip.
The rest is the same as the smaller version.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.12

Infill:

Anything you want (100% on the body is preferred for weight)

Notes:

The yellow bits might be a tight fit and require a small bit of scraping and pressing them in.

title: X-Axis Belt Tensioner for NoelJean's X Gantry (608ZZ Idler)

description.text:
Only hardware required is 608ZZ skate bearing, which you should already have.

I seem to have lost the original bearing that was used, so it didnt fit on the bolt. I also wanted to be able to apply tension to the belt, since im using a different belt that doesnt hook into the notches enough to hold tension.

See screenshot for assembly. Bolt and nut goes through, bearing goes on bolt. Thread belt through before putting nut and bolt through the slot. Body bends around (works with PLA) and grabs onto the hex head and bolt. Larger diameter bolt is threaded through body, goes into a slot in the pad. Pad's curved surface matches the curved surface of the gantry.

With this system, it will never slip and lose tension.

Part of my $0 Oneup rebuild.

title: Minimalistic V-Slot jig for delta rods
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 2017, Aug. 28th

The stl is not manifold due to the bottom hole and the width of the notch that goes into the extrusion being the same diameter which results in a wall thickness of 0 at this specific point. Repairing the model does not result in a significantly different print result so feel free to print as is or repair it before printing - it doesn't matter.

original post:

While most jigs for Traxxas 5347 rod ends are designed so that you glue the rod ends to the carbon rods before inserting the ball joints and do so for all six rods at once, this design takes a different approach.

One rod at a time and ball joints inserted.

Advantages:

  • You get to choose the best rod ends before glueing them to the rods. (I had to go through 36 to find 12 acceptable ones.)
  • The jig stays in place really well all of the time and if your rods were cut to the same length (the place where I ordered mine did an excellent job) you'll end up with a pretty consistent total rod length for all your rods in a single glueing session. (As opposed to 6 at once jigs, where you basically have to manage six different lengths, parallelism, etc.)

Disadvantages:

  • It potentially takes longer, since you can only glue the rods consecutively. (Please don't work around this by printing more jig parts and glue rods for the same printer on different jigs at the same time. ;))

The holes are for M3 and M4 screws. If you've come this far, you'll figure out the rest by yourself by looking at the pictures.

Printer:

Taront3rD

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I suggest printing the part upside down.
Drill out the bridged layer in the M4 hole. It's only there to facilitate printing and allows for the part to be printed without supports.

title: Magnet  or Penny Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a spinner that didn't have exposed outer weights.
This design will either accommodate 3/4" X 3/16" button magnets or three pennies.
I like using magnets because you can use them to make each other spin, stick to fridge, etc.
To insert the weights just pause at the corresponding layer at the top of the magnets or pennies in each hole.
I did not include spinner caps because there are already plenty of good designs.
You can get the magnets at most craft stores, I picked up a 52 pack at Walmart for $6.

Tips:
Do not use supports otherwise your holes will get filled up.
Depending on your software use the option to not cross the outline for travel movements.
This keeps the holes free and clear of any strands of stray filament.
If you look at the pictures I paused right before layer 31 to get the magnets in place.
But this will change depending on what settings you use.

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Doesn't Matter

comments.author: DukeT

comments.text:
I updated the files to mm format.
It was scaled correctly it just depends on what your machine is setup to use.
Just because people use mm units doesn't mean it was scaled wrong.
I use S3d and it automatically detects whether or not it is in mm or inches and will change the file accordingly.
Yes I admit it should be in mm because that is what most machines use and I forgot to change the output file from my 3D model to stl to mm.
BTW, you don't need to tell me "That's hows it's done".
I spent my time drawing up the model, uploading files, writing directions, taking pictures, etc for others to use for free.
But then again no good deed goes unpunished.

author: CameraCopter

description.text:
For my greenhouse automation project I needed to mount a few small DC fans and I utilized OpenSCAD again to build it. The mount consists of a baseplate and two brackets.
The brackets fit in slots on both sides of the base plate and the fan is clamped in between them. This is supposed to be a tight fit but the initial versions were too tight. It took me two iterations of the brackets and three for the base plate to get them right.
All the resizing was done exclusively by changing variables, the code has remained the same. As such it should be possible to also use this for slightly bigger fans.
If needed you can use my customizable distance holder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2277424 ) to mount them on the correct height. Have Fun!

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Sliced with Cura 2.3.1. Top, bottom & wall thickness are all 0.8mm.
I used a small skirt, just to get the extruder started.
You need to print one base plate and two brackets; this can be done in one printjob by loading the required parts before saving to file. The brackets are symmetrical so there is no left or right bracket.

Printing Matching Parts

For me this project was somewhat of a learning experience regarding tolerances and the printing of matching parts. As such it has increased my respect for the people who are able to make designs that fit even when printed on different printers.
Anyway, for my Anet A8 it fits now. The nozzle diameter turned out to be the magical number. When I used that value for the 'clearance' parameter (which defines the side clearance for the slots) the parts were fitting with some slight pressure.
When changing the parameters, make sure to set them identically for both the brackets and the base plate.

print_settings.Notes:: For the Tray, best to print with PLA as it is a big object and PLA warps less.

description.text:
AN OPEN SOURCE CRICOTHYROTOMY TRAINER THAT IS COMPLETELY USER MODIFIABLE!

No expensive/special replacement skins required!  Uses readily available consumable items, making the C.U.T. the easiest, most affordable, and effective basic trainer on the market.

We have all seen them.   The ingenious homemade Crico Trainers cobbled together out of ventilator tubing, tape, and other items that one could find on the shelf.  No doubt these homemade Crico Trainers have served their purpose.  But if your looking to replace your homemade Cric Trainer with something more durable, easier to use, and still affordable, then you have come to the right place. 

Welcome to the C.U.T.!

3D print one yourself, Or head to our website and purchase there!

Thanks for looking!

Design & Business LLC
https://www.designbusinessllc.com

12/09/17 - Update

  • I've added two new Overlay units.
    -First the "Raised_Cricothyroid_Cartilage_Overlay_Unit.stl" which has a slightly raised thyroid cartilage. See picture for difference.
    -And also the "BETA_FLEX_Cricothyroid_Cartilage_Overlay_Unit.stl" which must be printed in a flexiable material as the opening is smaller and must flex in order for a Trach tube to be inserted. It has not been tested, hence the BETA term.

DESCRIPTION
Its called the Cricothyrotomy Unlimited Trainer or C.U.T. for short. When used along side more advanced training devices, the C.U.T. can help keep Cricothyrotomy procedures proficient, while keeping training session costs low. Use the C.U.T. for reviewing the basic practices of Cricothyrotomy at a very low price per session. Once the basic practices have been taught, then more advance and costlier devices can be used to get the finer points down pat.

This is open source, and if you want all the 3d CAD files please see this link, https://cad.onshape.com/documents/58fb52702e4c33108485ff45/w/e9c82842082a8da89920cf91/e/e63475c8b3864495c9eb34df

Please use, share, and modify at will. See pictures and video for how to use and other parts sources.

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

16% or greater

Notes:

I found that printing the Cricothyrotomy Neck Unit in PLA and with no lower solid layer helps prevent warping. I usually have 10 outer layers up to 1mm high to help get the edges to stick to the bed. No supports is required.

Use Semi-Flex for the Cricothyroid Cartilage Overlay Unit. You will need supports. Semi-Flex seems to be the best material for the right amount of flex and rigidity.

For the Tray, best to print with PLA as it is a big object and PLA warps less.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KBR4zlG0XlI" ></iframe>

description.text:
A very simple yet effective design. These G-Clip style Garden Grabbers are ideal to quickly join two thin round parts that are under tension. In the picture I've used them to join together pieces of snow fence that I use as lattice as well as deer fence and bird netting. These can also be used to join vines to fences and other uses you can think of.

Print them a few at a time or use the 32GardenGrabbers.stl file to print a batch of 32.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any, larger/faster is better

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You can print these in any material you wish but consider the use. If these will be out in the sun and you want to use PLA make sure it isn't a dark color (like black). PETG and ABS work great too. There are no small details so print using the lowest resolution in order to get these out quick. Maximum layer height for maximum strength.

Use 100% infill since these are small and you want them as rigid as possible.
I looked for something similar to print and to my surprise I could not find anything so I made these up.

This is a model of a rotary-vee motor. A very unusual motor configuration with little practical application, according to NASA. This is a demonstration model that was brought to my attention on a post by thingiuser jamesdavid on my v-12 motor.
Here is the link he posted: http://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19890016636_1989016636.pdf

Right now it needs to be printed with soluble support as a complete model but I will be laying out the parts tray to be printed separately on a TOM or Replicator etc, so check back.
I don't quite know what would be appropriate for the rods as they won't print well, too thin and tall. (could scale them perhaps) I was going to use acrylic rods and rezn-bond them together.
The body and cylinders will print just fine. (I will upload them as separate files too)
I have provided the source file for you to play should it strike you to do so. I model in Rhino. Stay tuned for my printing results! Suggestions are welcome!

description.text:
SAFETY WARNING: DO NOT LOOK AT THE SUN DIRECTLY, ESPECIALLY NOT THROUGH A TELESCOPE. PERMANENT EYE DAMAGE WILL RESULT.

I am not responsible for any loss or damage caused by the use of these designs, they are provided for information only. All use is at your own risk.

This set is designed to make solar observations through a mobile phone (Nexus 6P, but you can remix the design for your own phone) using a small spotter scope. My scope's eyepiece has a 45mm external diameter and a 72mm externai diameter at the objective end. Of course, if your measurements differ, you can alter the design. If you're not using Blender like me, you may have to scale the STL files anyway - Blender seems to not get scaling quite right on STL files.

In use, it is best to align the telescope first using a white sheet of card to obtain an image of the sun, then attach the filter holder and phone holder. You can drill a hole into the side of the eyepiece tube and attach a screw if necessary to hold the phone firmly in place. It works best if the phone is upside-down, as it moves the centre of gravity over the telescope.

The filter holder is designed to take solar filter sheets, cut to size. You'll need to glue (or friction weld) the two parts together. Use only a good quality solar filter sheet (such as Thousand Oaks or Baader).

Note The "Lens Check" file does not need to be printed; I've included it in case you are remixing the phone holder. It can be inserted into the eyepiece tube so that you can check the phone camera lens is centred in the eyepiece tube easily.

The picture of the sun included above was the first I took using this setup, so not great quality, as I need a little more practice. I hope you'll agree it's a decent start though.

Printer:

Aney A8 using RAMPS 1.4 and Skynet firmware

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15% is fine

Notes:

Use supports on the phone holder to support the overhang on the eyepiece. The design includes internal supports for the internal overhangs. On my printer, these are a snap to remove.

The filter holder will need to be split and printed as two parts. Simply glue them together when done. No brim or raft is needed.

Case for the Pine64 SBC

Has a hole in the top to paste a 25x25 heasink on the A64 cpu.
Got the heatsinks in china: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-20pcs-Aluminum-Heat-Sink-25-x-25-x-10mm-Electrical-Accessories/1990534382.html
Just leveled .STL to build platform. Previous file was hard to print. Thanks to Spuddie007 for original download.

description.text:
Crossbow for match

Here is a crossbow for match.

It takes elastic, which must go through the holes of the bow and go around the loop to stretch it.
Slipped this one under the body of the crossbow.
Clip the trolley over the body and move the top elastic over and under which will balance the thrust.
The dimensions of the assembled crossbow are: Length = 6,2cm, Width = 7,7 cm, Height = 1,58 cm
Enjoy the game.

Layer thickness 0.2
Hull thickness 1
Fill rate 30
Temperature of 220C ° printing
Media Type all over

Arbalète pour allumette

Voici une arbalète pour allumette.

Il faut un élastique, qu'il faut passer dans les trous de l'arc et faire le tour de la boucle pour le tendre.
Clissé celui-ci sous le corps de l’arbalète.
Clipser le chariot sur le corps et faire passer l'élastique haut dessus et en dessous se qui équilibrera la poussée.

My husband and I weren't satisfied with RonnyLULU's version, so I tweaked it a fair amount. I'm still tweaking it. We eat a lot of boxed cereal and get things in the same-ish thickness cardboard, so we have a lot of that sitting around, for just such projects as this.
I gave clearances at the fold points for thicker media, as the V-points deformed the cardboard we originally used (I think it was a UPS corrugated box). The photographed box was using a Totino's Pizza Roll box panel.
The oval window is on a separate layer which I haven't yet printed out, because of the box's stability.
We might lengthen the tab a little that tucks in to secure the bottom, and it will need a dot or two of glue.

author: lillelupo

description.text:
So I recently bought my wife a used 2004 Acura MDX. One thing that I found was that the clip for the center console/arm rest was broken. The dealer had just put the parts inside the center console, which was nice, since then I had something to work from. I thought that it might be a little bit of a challenge for OpenSCAD, but I figured I'd give it a shot. This part may fit other model years, but I can only speak to how it works on our 2004, Perfect I might add.

The OpenSCAD file that is attached is none too pretty and I didn't do any documenting of it, but I figured that it was for this small part, so I didn't see much of a point in it.

I have ordered some plastic in a similar color as the old part, so as soon as that comes in, I will re-print it in that color. For now I just did it in white.

Assembly and installation of this part is simple. Open the armrest cover and remove the two screws that hold the clip assembly in place shown by the red arrows in the image. Next, remove the round pivot pin marked with the blue arrow being careful to note the orientation of the spring. The spring has one pin that is bent, and one that is straight. Hook the bent pin in the notch under the plate with the screws, and the straight pin in the hole on the new clip marked with the yellow arrow in the picture. Slide the pin through the side hole going through the new clip and the spring to secure it in place. Screw the clip assembly back into the armrest and you are done.

More about me

For more information about me and other projects and things by me, take a look at my websirte at https://dan.bemowski.info/

title: Sir PIgglesby Right Flower Belt V2 (Untested)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A user had pointed out that the right hand flower belt did not fit as well as it could. Whilst I haven't had any other reports regarding this piece, I had a quick look (whilst taking a break from wiring:-)) and have uploaded what I hope is an improvement.

The deal is this. I'm not at home at the moment and I don't have my printer with me (doing house rebuild stuffs). Whilst I don't have problem fixing mesh errors without a print test, I am very cautious about trying anything regarding fittings without a decent testing process. If you want to act as my tester then I have provided this file for you to try because I know how frustrating it can be when you want to finish a project.

Again, this is untested. Which is why it has been posted as separate from the main project.

All feedback encouraged.

author: Synchron

print_settings.Notes:: multible movable parts

description.text:
This is a universal filament guide that can be used to guide the filament string to the extruder stepper motor.

It can be simply attached to the extruded rod (7mm groove) with an M4 bolt.
Attach it anyhere needed. The ball head AND the holding ring are both movable 360°.
Use multiple things to maintain sweet filament guiding all the way from the roll to the feeder.

I included the blender file, so feel free to tweak it and maybe add something cool like an included filament filter or so to it.

My first Thing so let me know what you thin(g).

author: AngelTree

description.text:
I have not printed yet the v82, but it contains fix for issues found in the previous revision.

The supports are a bit painfull to remove, it may be better to print with a soluble filament for supports but I have only one filament.

Better printed in black, and, may be possible to be paint to "hide" supports removable white spots.

It can't fit three 18650 but it may fit three 16650.
I will probably use a standard li-ion battery with a pcb-addon to charge from usb and a boost to get ~7V from output (2.5W, 12V for 5W TX)

Various notes or not fixed (yet?):

  • the door may need a little sanding to fit properly on one left or right side. maybe 0.3mm less on width

Battery pack v82 fixes:

  • wall with ends too fragile (the one right before the hole for the "push to remove" button)
  • holes of <=1mm too small
  • hole for the release pack too small
  • removed .5mm of one side of the rail to make it fit properly

description.text:

these fit cable mod cables they may fit others.

check out my other items for PC mainly around my H440 case.

none really

I planned on sanding the top and bottom but didn't think i need it after i test fitted the first.

free cad

I use free cad. It was simple. rectangle mirrored on the X&Y with 16 holes mirrored as well. pad that. then another sketch with series of small squares mirrored to make the opening and pocket that. then just some fillets all around.

I drew this in OpenScad. If anyone wants the origional code, send me a message.

OpenScad drawing

10 half cylinders 1/2" in diameter evenly spaced around a central core with a thin disc top and bottom and a 0.072" diam. bore. It can be attatched to the generator to cause rotation clockwise or counter clockwise, by just flipping it over.

I printed it on a modified Printerbot Simple 1401 makers kit that I assembled and them modified to add a glass table with an increased x dimension of 300mm. I use glue stick diluted with a drop of water and evenly smeared to cover the print area to attain bed adhesion.

author: wolfeness04

description.text:
This extruder is derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275593. I purchased an FLSun i3 a Prusa I3 knock-off with a 2020 aluminum extrusion frame. The printer is pretty good, but of course had a few annoying quirks. One of these was that generally to load filament I had to remove the bowden tube and the fitting. The supplied extruder seems to be derived from the original, or one very much like the original. To over come the filament loading problem I reduce the distance from the drive gears to the filament guide and flared the opening. I also redesigned the lever. I broke the first one I built so I have also strengthened it. Finally I changed the size of the hole for the 3mm nut so that it would not rotate.

I use the 5mm threaded fitting for the bowden tube, I cut threads in the extruder for the fitting with a 5mm self-threading bolt I made.

comments.text: The Y-Chain EXT Mount is only used if you are going to use a Y-Axis Chain. It connects the chain to the Y extrusion on the left side of the bed. The Extruder Extension lifts the Bowden extruder up off of the top extrusion because I found that when printing very tall prints the Bowden tube would kick and cause jamming without it. Both of these are optional and not needed.

author: Toxiccrisco

description.text:
This is my third attempt at a dog toy for my jack russel terrier. She loves it!

I had the idea after I found her regularly "stealing" caps of spray cans, catty them around and sticking her nose into them for hours. I added an obstacle and so the back of the cup becomes a food reservoir.

You can fill it with cotton-cheese and/or other treats. I also added two slits where you can clamp in treats to make it even harder for the dog to reach to the inside. I use different treats and clamp it inside such that she has to work to get stuff out. In the rear area is a rounded corner such that it is easier to clean and other edges are all smoothed too.

The outside cylinder is slightly tilt such that it does not roll completely straight but in a wide arc. I thought that may be more fun for her and keeps the toys in a closer area.

As material I used BDP Flax and PETg. Both are ok for contact with food and BDP Flax would probably even digested (partly) if she could break it. It was printed with 3 perimeter outlines and 100% infill. The PETg version was printed without cooling to make the layers bonding very strong. The BDP Flax version was printed with "higher heat" which makes this material pretty hard. I also used it for coffee cups which are working and still looking decent after months of daily usage.

This model has an opening of 65m and is for small dogs. I think one can scale it and it will fit other breeds well. You may not be able to print it with 100% infill at bigger size but adding some perimeters may make it chew resistant enough (or not).
I created this because I found this cool design and wanted nickels instead of bearings.

remixed_from.title: Wall mount for Oral B electric toothbrush

title: Oral B Tooth Brush Holder Station

description.text:
I took Villekl's Oral B wall mount base unit design and remixed it into an Oral B Toothbrush station for two. I raised height of the base charge pucks units for more rigidity and added a compartment in the center for toothpaste and small bathroom stuff like nail clippers, dental floss ect... The largest center compartment will hold a medium sized tube of paste, the very largest tubes might be kind of a tight fit depending the brand and size of the cap like those flip caps.
Also made a separate insert in case you only want one charger puck in the station and one less power cord.
Can also be mounted to the wall.

This particular print was too large for my MP Mini 120mm cubed print area to print as one complete piece. So, I split it into 3 sections. Left base, Right base and Center stack then glued it with cyanoacrylate glue. Need to make a few trimmings with the knife but other than that it fit perfect. I will upload these .stl files as well for those who don't have a large print bed.

Monoprice MP Mini

title: Wanhao D6/Monoprice Drive Block for Flexible Filaments
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another take on a drive block for the extruder of the Zortrax/Wanhao D6/Monoprice Ultimate clonage for flexible filaments.

Version 2 has a very tight fit for the 10.8mm diameter, 38 tooth Robotdigg Filament drive gear 4 flat shaft for nema17 stepper (RDGFDB) and the Micro-swiss lever for the Wanhao D6. The original D6 drive gear will also fit. The Robotdigg gear has wicked sharp teeth and thus much better retraction abilities compared to the D6 gear. No slipping anymore. You may have to sand the inner diameter a little. Clean up the print by drilling through the filament guide and smoothing the upper entry. I printed this in PETG but PLA or ABS will work just fine.

I can finally print large projects in Ninfaflex on the Wanhao D6 with this, a silicone boot and the Micro-swiss hotend for the Wanhao D6.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

PETG, 0.150mm

comments.text:
Thanks Empericus! I can now print TPE.
Suggestion: the hole for the stepper's alignment collar should be smaller. Currently it has enough movement to bind up the drive gear. Sanding the part above the drive gear got around that. The guide above the drive gear is why I chose this part over another, to make loading filament easier. However, tight clearance above the drive gear isn't important. so the model could be a bit more lenient there.
comments.author: trayracing

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. Suggestions are always appreciated. The tolerances are tight here and it is difficult to have a version that fits all different gears, filaments and settings being used. Might make changes when I need to print a new one although didn't notice any abrasion etc yet. The part on top is there for stability and prevent wrapping during operation when the stepper/extruder is getting hot.
comments.author: trayracing

comments.text: Would it be possible to open the gear hole a little bit, I have have the d4 gear and it doesnt fit.
comments.author: festaman

comments.text: Probably easier to just sand the inner diameter with 320 grid. Every filament and setup might create slight variations. Don't have a d4 gear what is the exact diameter in mm?
comments.author: festaman

comments.text: Its a commoon upgrade to the id and the d6.  I may reprint it with more perimeters , when i was sanding it i broke through my walls. Its a 12mm OD gear
comments.author: Empiricus

comments.text: I can see if I find one. These tight adaptations required a lot of test prints and corrections to make sure that the filament is transported  nicely also during retractions and also can be removed easily. The upper entry is part of this as well. Looks like a simple mod but it is not. I have a whole bunch of gears that I tested before I settled on the one I mentioned in the description. It is easy to take the stl file import into fusion 360 convert to BPrep and adapt to your needs.
comments.author: festaman

comments.text: How many perimeters and what infill % do you suggest?
comments.author: trayracing

comments.text: I used 2 perimeters and 100% infill. 5 bottom and 5 top layers.. Simplify 3D.

title: B'Struder base plate for Anet A8

description.text:
Base plate for the B'Struder. It mounts the extruder to the left top offset backwards to allow full height X-Axis travel. Filament has a straight vertical path from a reel on the left. Uses existing screws/holes and has built in cover for the Z rod.

Mirror it in your slicer to have it right side mounted.

Also included is the spring bushing to increase spring tension. The springs that come with the A8 are too weak to use with the B'Struder and the bushing adds enough tension to use them.

description.text:
This is a remix of a mod by James Sprecker on the FolgerTech 3D Printers Facebook group.

This bracket was designed to use a 10-32 screw and nut. It can be modified to accept a 5M and TNut by enlarging the slot just slightly.

The nice thing about this mod that James worked out, is that you don't have to trap another belt around the lead screws. And, it uses the existing frame mounting, just replacing the M5x10 screws with M5x16.

NOTE: The length of GT2 belt that I used, as pictured, is 696mm, but I have tried a 760mm and the slot in the bracket is long enough to work with that length.

-Make sure if 3D it's functional.
NGSS CCSS

Designing Modular Longboard Wheel I came with this idea because of a need, I wanted to make an electric longboard but when I had to make the drive train I had to use a lot of tools (drill, CNC, etc.). So I decided to make an modular Longboard wheel, when the tire is out of use we can change it by printing another one from polyurethane.

-Find the problem or the improvement.
-Find a solution. (This is what makes you an engineer).
-Makea plan.
-Design it in a 3D software.
-Print it.
-Test it.

PC
CATIA V5
3D Printer
PLA
ABS
PETG
TPU
• Engineer
100 minutes

This is the 3D model of how it will look. Next step is to 3D print the outer shell (orange) in TPU (ThermoPlastic Polyurethane) and the inner part (black) I have to find through testing best material to be steady on bumps, tricks, and vibration.
But, you already find longboard tires, those tires are for in wheel electric motors for... longboards. You can buy this tires and make your own inner part.

A Lidar derived 3D model of the University of Minnesota Campus at ~1:20,000 scale.

This model was derived from Lidar datasets.
Lidar was acquired through MNTopo and processed in Quick Terrain Modeler to create a DSM. From there it was exported into .STL format through a QGIS Plugin.

Any questions on development of this model are welcome: [email protected]

comments.text: This is really cool --- how exactly did you make it? What are Lidar data sets?
comments.author: REX647

comments.text: Hello! Thank you! Lidar data sets created similarly to radar, except use light laser beams rather than sound waves. When the beams are bounced back they are collected into a several million point cloud that can be interpolated. This model had about 42 million points in it. You can find Lidar data at MNTopo here: http://arcgis.dnr.state.mn.us/maps/mntopo/ Minnesota is one of the very few states to have statewide Lidar data collected and is free for the public to use!
comments.author: REX647

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cuvjIOITMlB

Red Cross charm. The cross has a hole through it so it can be added to a lanyard or string.

There versions

  • Easy print with holddown ears
  • Large group print
  • Tight group print

There is an new version of this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2484766

This test jig is designed to analyse the dimensional accuracy of a printer using engineering methods. But don't be afraid: an excel sheet is included which performs all the math. You just have to print, measure and type in the numbers. A caliper is needed.

Note that calibration is normally not needed for modern printers and calibration cubes are very coarse. Check: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mbn1ckR86Z8

Why this is more accurate than other calibration/testing methods:

  • The edges have chamfers to eliminate effects from the first and last layers.
  • Corners are rounded to minimize effects caused by sudden direction change.
  • Different than a calibration cube the excel sheet does analyze the diffence in the length of the colums instead of their total lenght. This reduces the influence some effects wich would distort the calibration like a effective thicker wall due to z-wobble or over extrusion.
  • It uses the total length availiable for typical calipers (155mm), reducing the influence of random efects
  • By analyzing 5 values per axis instead of 1 the influence of random effects is reduced.

A derived recomendation for design tolerances is included based using a typical engineering approach (3sigma).

The excel sheet is protected against unintended changes but there is no password. So you can easily deativate the protection to edit the formulas if needed.

In order to get some statistical data: If you have performed this test if you could post the standard deviation for X and Y, the printer and slicer used in the comment section. Thanks in advance.

Update 1.5.2017: Small corrections in the STL file. Small version (145mm) added for smaller heatbeds

Update 4.5.2017: Z Axis added and now all distance differences are evaluated to get more data and a more accurate caluculation. Histogram added.

comments.author: TomsCreations

comments.text: Thats by purpose because the mean of the C16 and C23 is used as a reference. Note: Always the difference to this reference is evaluated instead of absolute length. This eliminates patially some effects which should not be concidered when calibrating (wobble, under/over extrusion).
comments.author: TomsCreations

comments.text: Thank you very much! Great information and excel calculation sheet!
comments.author: TomsCreations

comments.text:
That's a guideline when designing parts in CAD.
For example: You design a shaft for a bearing with a 7mm inner hole. If the shaft diameter is exactly 7mm in the stl file sometimes the printed shaft will be smaller and sometimes larger than 7mm. So sometimes it fits sometimes not. (in the best case this is a 50/50 chance). So either you will have to sand, drill, etc until the parts fit or you design the schaft to be slightly smaller. To have a guideline how much smaller it should be engineers often use 3 times the standard deviation of the manufacturing process. (3sigma).
Thats a short explanation of a quite complex topic. I hope it answers your question.
comments.author: TomsCreations

comments.text: Thank you for responding so quickly!
comments.author: lukeskymuh

comments.text:
It is a standard procedure in mechanical design and a design not concidering the limitations of the manufacturing process is not accepted in real engineering. Normally this is done by defining assymetric tolerances which are condiddering when manufacturing, but in 3D printing the CAD and CAM (Computer aided manufacturing) is merging. So I don't see any alternative.
The difficulty is to get a good set of standard values which fit to every printer, slicer, filament. The statistical methods used are a first try but they defenetly do not cover all effects (filament, temperature, vibrations, etc). So I concider them more like a rough guideline rather than precise values.
comments.author: TomsCreations

description.text: The insulator retaining ring on the Makerbot plastruder (Mk3 and Mk4) takes a lot of punishment. If it breaks, you can't print. With these instructions, you can make an emergency replacement that'll keep you going until you can buy / print a replacement. NOTE: This isn't a precision part. It's a quick hack to get you printing again. Using this as a permanent part isn't recommended. Your best bet is, once your printer is repaired, immediately print a replacement retainer and one or two spares.

Print the attached image (click on the image to the left and use the "Original Image" link). At full size, it should be 1.75"x1.5" (44.5mm x 38mm). Print it onto sticker paper or a label sheet if you've got it. Otherwise, use regular paper and tape or glue it down.
Cut a piece of acrylic (roughly 3/16" or 5mm thick) to the size of the rectangle. I used 0.22" acrylic sheet from the local hardware store and it seemed to work fine.
Trim the printout to the size of the rectangle and attach it to the piece of acrylic.
Drill holes where marked. A hand-held electric drill will do in a pinch but a drill press is better. The small holes are 1/8" or 3mm and the large hole is 5/8" or 16mm.
It won't be pretty but it'll work until you can get a proper replacement.

title: Project Aeolus: Vertical Axis Wind Turbine

description.text:
This is the first version of my vertical axis wind turbine. (V.A.W.T.) I've taken to calling the VAWT Project Aeolus, after the Greek god of wind. The goal of this project is to not only reduce my carbon footprint but also do it in an aesthetically pleasing manner. It is my belief that pure function is not enough to convince people to switch to clean sources of energy. When function is paired with beauty, a spinning bit of plastic can capture both clean energy and the imagination of those who view it.

This VAWT is composed of four easy to 3d-print parts. This modular design offers two advantages. The ability to print individual parts means that it is more accessible to printers with a smaller build volume. Additionally, the turbine can be stacked to any height without compromising its structural integrity. In essence this turbine is comprised of two types of vertical wind turbines. A helical Darrieus turbine, and a Savonius style wind turbine.

Please feel free to ask as many questions as you can! Even if is sounds like a silly question! I certainly learn an awful lot by reflecting on a process, or explaining why I designed something a particular way.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I've already accounted for tolerance in this model, but you may need to adjust it depending on your printer. The center piece is designed for a 12mmx26mmx9mm Thrust Bearing (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBH8TW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and the screw holes are designed for 12mm long, countersunk, m3 screws. I used 12mm linear rods (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBJ0CA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) which are clamped together with 12mm clamping collars ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0020800IC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). These clamping collars also hold up the thrust bearings.

Each hole on the Vane Component and Center Component must be tapped using an m3 tap (unless you are using different sized screws). I would also recommend sanding the vanes to improve their aerodynamics.

I did a lot experimentation with post-print finishing techniques for this piece. I did this to enhance both the form and function of the VAWT. Form from function and function from form being a major theme of my work. For the finish seen in the photographs, I first used a spray filler primer to smooth out the 3d print layers. Then I painted it using Montana Gold spray paint. (Montana Gold is the brand of spray paint. Gold isn't the color, they just call it that for some reason. It comes in loads of beautiful colors) Then I clear coated it using Montana's gloss varnish. (I always recommend using the same brand of clear coat and spray paint. Different brands sometimes chemically react with each other which can cause bubbles to form in the clear coat) And finally, I used a standard automotive clear coat polish to give it a mirror finish. (I also did some wet sanding in between each step, starting with 600 grit for the filler primer and finishing with 1500 grit before using the clear coat polish) It's time consuming but there are no special resources required. I was amazed by the professional quality finish, despite using only spray paint! I am extremely fascinated with the post processing of 3d prints.

As for the base, it's actually made from angle iron and iron round stock, which I tig welded together and then powder coated white. The stand is mainly for display purposes, so I could move it easily and subject it to light test winds. Heavier winds can blow it over, so it's not a permanent solution. Ideally you would just drill a 12mm hole in a fixed structure, with some kind of fastening system, to securely attach it. I'm not sure if a 3d printed stand would be strong enough to safely secure it, but i'll definitely test it out and upload any functional stands. Accessibility being a major goal of this project, a printable stand would absolutely make the turbine more accessible to people without the same metal working resources.

Hi Hashtag_Mike
I installed it on my fence and it started running very well. Then I put some bearings on the shaft and turned it the right way up (as per your picture) and it does not spin anymore?? Turn it up sight down and it spins very well. Running anti-clockwise. I would have thought that it would run both ways?? What is your experience?
comments.author: jackBrinkman

comments.text:
Hey Jack,
That is very odd! Mine Is able to spin the same speed, whether it's right-side up or up-side down. There might be some friction when you have it right-side up, like its rubbing against the rod or something. Or, you may have installed the vanes up-side down, but it looks fine in your picture. Aerodynamically, it should work both way.

Use the Customizer tool (click the button above) to create a series of lined-up polygonal through-holes within a solid block. You can define the diameter of each hole, a universal offset value to customize the fit, the spacing between the holes, and the thickness of the object. This is useful for testing and generating perfectly sized holes (for press-fits or whatever else) with your printer, and the resulting object can be a good starting place for more complicated parts.

This is inspired and adapted from nophead's polygonal hole test object and this blog post. In a nutshell, accurate sizing for printed holes depends on two factors. First, the number of polygons should be equal to twice the diameter (in mm) of the hole. Second, the diameter should be adjusted to account for the straight lines making up the polygon. Finally, a global offset value provides a way to increase or decrease the hole sizes overall so you can achieve a desired fit or clearance.

description.text:
Snap-on arm designed to hold a 6.9-7mm dia x 6 mm long nylon spacer/bushing at just about any angle to provide a very low-friction filament guide. Your choice of ~3cm or ~7cm offset. Fits 2020 Openbeam (not planning to add instances for other openbeam sizes, sorry).

This is my first posted original design! I refined it to print nicely on my AnyCubic Kossel XL, which needs about .30 of spacing between moving parts (right now) for the edges to not fuse together. This makes for some play in the joints, and might make for more play on a better-tuned printer, but I figure play is okay, and it works very well for running filament down from my top-mounted spool through 3 long-arms and one short-arm*.

*5.17.17 update: I ended up printing one more long and one more short over what's shown in the pictures to create a more evenly constrained arc through the 180 degrees down-to-up.

Printer:

AnyCubic Linear Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Intended for PLA printing due to the bridges required by the joints.

Pop in a 6.9mm nylon spacer!

I chamfered the inside lips on both ends with a few twists on the end of a large, sharp drill bit.

For reference, I'm pretty sure these are the type of nylon spacers that I used (I got mine 4 years ago and can't recall from whence), although maybe you'd want to find them in a smaller quantity: https://www.amazon.com/3mmx6mm-Spacer-Support-Holder-Standoff/dp/B00R1LKDIU/ref=sr_1_29?srs=3049510011&ie=UTF8&qid=1493553752&sr=8-29&keywords=uxcell+nylon+7mm+spacer

An extension for the dead pedal of 2nd generation Mini (Cooper, Clubman, Convertible, Coupe, and Roadster). Elevates the foot rest for your left foot for better ergonomics.

Currently this is a WIP, it has screw holes for using self-tapping plastic screws if you like, however future versions will have a less destructive method of fixed mounting. Using high strength double sided tape, like that used for adhering automotive exterior trim panels, seems to be OK but use at your own risk.

title: Zlin Z-242 frame model (esc: 1/64) (No 3D print, CNC routing)

description.text:
For more models and paid version please visit my cult3d profile:

https://cults3d.com/es/usuarios/guaro3d/creaci%C3%B3n

on instagram: @guaro3d

This is a model that I designed a while ago, before having a 3D printer, I have seen some people here that have CNC Router, so maybe they will find it useful.

The model is designed to be cut in 1 mm plastic sheet, the openings on the pieces have this dimension, so if you want to cut it on a thicker material you will have to scale the model up, at this scale (1/64) is a really challenging cut, I used a 1/32in 2 flutes flat milling bit to cut it on my Zentoolworks 7x7, it took about an hour and a half to cut.

I have attached the .dxf file with all the flat pieces and a .stl (not mean to be 3d printed, is not water tight) model of the completed model.

Please let me know what you think, as always your comments and tips will be greatly appreciated.

Greetings

After printing

Glue it together and catch 'em all!

Was asked by a friend to print off a local mountain so I built model of it and printed it off.
I used sketch-up blender and cura to make this model work.

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layer height, 0.4mm nozzel, 40mm/s print speed.

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Scaled to 16% for my printer
Set to 40mm/s

Sanding

The model has some small defects on the top from it stringing on some of the sharp peaks. I has some fine sandpaper and touched up the peaks and the base.

Step 1: Skepch-up

Used Sketch-Up to import land models from google earth. Had to take multiples snapshots of the ground because the area needed was so large. It was then exported as a OBJ.

Step 2: Blender

Took the 4 shots of the mountain into blender and combined them into one solid model. I added sides and a base to the model and exported it as an STL.

Step 3: Cura

Used Cura to slice the model.

remixed_from.author: Debio
remixed_from.title: Da Vinci 1.0 E3d Titan + V6 Direct Drive "Coyote" Carriage BETA

title: Da Vinci 1.0 E3d Titan + V6 Direct Drive "Coyote" Carriage v2

description.text:
Alternative carriage for the XYZ Printing Da Vinci 1.0 (mine is a 1.0A) printer using an E3D Titan extruder with an E3D v6 hotend.

Directions:

  • Print using ABS or another high-temperature-tolerant plastic at high infill (40%+) (it's designed to print on its side with the motor mounts on the bed-side and does require supports). I used eSUN PETG.
  • assemble carriage + stepper + extruder + hotend
  • Remove bushings from the Da Vinci factory carriage
  • Remove linear rails from the Da Vinci Y-axis carriages
  • Insert front bushings (I found that pressing the carriage down into the bushing on a table worked well if they were stubborn). Do not press them in completely - just get them far enough inserted that they're secure. Probably doesn't need to be more than halfway.
  • Insert a rail through the front bushings, tweaking as necessary until the rail moves smoothly back and forth. It's helpful to grab the outside of the bushings with a pair of pliers and rotate them so they settle into place. Remove the rail when done.
  • Insert the rear bushings, pushing them into the back of the carriage
  • Insert a rail through the rear bushings, tweaking as necessary until the rail moves smoothly back and forth.
  • Rock the rail back and forth a bit to get the rear bushings to move forward and backward in their slots. These bushings need to be a bit loose so they'll self-align - they aren't meant to be held rigidly. Remove the rail when done.
  • Put the now assembled carriage inside the x-axis belt loop inside the printer.
  • Reinsert the rails and screw them back into the Y-axis carriages.
  • Press the square nuts into the bottom of the carriage (4)
  • Stack up the belt cover, cooling fan duct, and endstop flag and insert screws to hold them together.
  • Screw the accessory pieces into the four mounting points on the carriage.
  • Assemble BLTouch mount if needed, insert two mounting screws on back of carriage, and mount it.
  • Insert cooling fan and attach via screw hole on endstop flag.
  • Insert three upper square nuts and attach upper wiring bracket
  • Wire wire wire, attaching to the upper bracket as desired.

The benefits:

  • cool totally random name
  • extruder and hotend are accessible from the front
  • lots of space for assembly
  • reuses factory bushings
  • part cooling blower
  • split into pieces so others can design modifications

Feel free to offer feedback and/or call me nasty names at http://www.soliforum.com/topic/15009/e3d-titan-v6-direct-drive-coyote-carriage-beta/

description.text:
This is an extruder and hotend replacement 'kit' to switch to a z-axis induction probe and an aluminium finned hotend. It fits on the existing x-axis carriage (3 scews) and otherwise uses existing screws and nuts from the original assembly.

The probe is a LJ12A3-4-Z/BX such as the one here:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-Parts-Model-LJ12A3-4-Z-BX-Tubular-Inductive-Proximity-Sensor-Switch-NPN-3-Wire/32667956956.html

The hotend should be similar to this one:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Lastest-E3D-V6-Version-All-metal-J-head-Hotend-Wade-or-Bowden-Extruder-with-Heater-Thermistor/32287569625.html

Be sure to instruct the seller to send the 12V heater, 0.4mm nozzle and direct model.

If you get a different probe ensure you get an NPN type or are prepared to create a voltage divider. An NPN type probe will allow you to swap directly with the existing Z endstop.

Trim about 8mm off of the x-axis endstop extension which is part of the x-axis carriage. This should lineup the nozzle with X=0.

Configuration.h and Configuration_adv.h for Marlin v1.0.2 are provided.

Printer:

Migbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

For the most part supports are unnecessary but use your best judgement. The idler does require support.

description.text:

ShK is a peptide toxin that blocks the voltage-gated potassium channels Kv1.1, Kv1.3, Kv1.6, Kv3.2 and KCa3.1.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stichodactyla_toxin

STL file created using VMD:

description.text:
LED light strip holder to be used with economical 3528 LED strip to create LED light bar. I use it to mount on the underside of the 2020 aluminum frame to illuminate the print object. Each LED holder is 200mm long and fits 4 sections of LED light strip. Glue multiple pieces to create long LED bar.

The slot is beveled to help secure the LED strip. Simply remove the backing to expose the double sided tape and gently set the LED strip in the slot with a spatula/scraper tool.

The 3528 LED strip is 8.0x2.0mm, if you use other types such as 5050 which is 10.0x2.0mm, change the scales in width to fit.

The LED strip I used can be found here.
Inlay is glued in with superglue. Printed at .15mm layer height with 30% infill.

This is a simple camera mount for a FPV camera. This model has not been flown yet. It is part of a build that is in progress.

Installation instructions:

  1. Unscrew your lens
  2. Place lens into hole on mount
  3. Screw camera body onto len
  4. Focus camera
  5. Tighten down lens retainer ring
  6. Attach to frame using Scotch extreme mounting tape

Files:

  1. cammount.stl: The camera mount
  2. janky.scad: The scad file that contains the models that I use on my quadcopter.

Inlay on this one is very tight, but it will fit. I had to carefully push it in with a flat head screwdriver. Glue is also recommended before you press it in. Printed at .15mm layer height and 30% infill.

Succubus Horns

this is a quick Proof of concept Model for a pair Succubus Horns additional details to be carved on or painted onto the model after printing

BE WARNED:
Unless you have a perfect 3d printer, the spinner will not spin perfectly at first. I spent about 30 minutes spinning it and it began to spin a lot more smoothly.
DO NOT PRINT WITH SUPPORTS OR A RAFT. If you print with a support or a raft, the spinner will not work.

A Few Things You Can Add:
There are two caps that go onto the top and bottom of the centerpiece of the spinner. I recommend you glue them into the center. There are guiding poles to make sure they go in perfectly.
I added a few nickels to the ends of the spinner to make it spin better. It makes it feel more like a real spinner

This is a work in progress. You can check to see later updates on the project by following my thingiverse profile.

description.text:
Shotglass based on the pipes from super mario bros.

The original mario shots.stl is really more of a double shot and I found it took me longer than I wanted to print it and was a bigger shot than it needed to be. But if you want something to really fill up go for it.

The short version is a more reasonable size for a shotglass and prints faster.

As usual with food related things DON'T PRINT WITH ABS. IT IS NOT FOODSAFE AND POTENTIALLY TOXIC. you can get foodsafe PLA though your extruder may leach minor amounts of stuff into it too.

print_settings.Notes:: For this print to be scannable it must be printed in two colors. To achieve dual colors, the filament must be switched after the 1mm layer. This is done by entering pause code in the g-code.

description.text:
This is a 3d printed Snapchat code. The code will scan and direct to a website. For scalability high contrast is necessary. In one color it can be used for decorative purpose only.

These codes have been produced by CustomGhostCodes.com.

Print in Black filament and switch to yellow filament after the 1mm layer has finished. This will produce a scannable code.

Getting your own code:
If you want to use your own code, there are a few steps to achieve this.

Download your Snapcode SVG from Snapchat
Go into your favorite design program and pull the SVG into a model.
Export to a .STL file
Slice with your printer settings.
Add pause code to switch filament color.
Those are all the steps and you can produce your own code.

If you want this process done for you check out www.CustomGhostCodes.com
They will create your STL or complete the entire process for you.

description.text:
CTC I3 Pro B Chinese Ebay Plywood 3D Printer Firmware
I did not create this firmware I only made it work with the geeetech 2560 Rev A board.

Things to know,

1) This firmware is for the geeetech 2560 Rev A board, with the Atmega 1280 chip "yes some of the boards have the this chip I think as a way to cut cost, but if you manage to flash the board with the new marlin firmware you will break it. I learned this the hard way. I spent weeks learning the firmware and the board and the chip to find out the flashing process is difrent from most of the material you see online. so here it is."

2) When you set up the Arduino connection to your printer you must use 2 important settings 1 You must select the Atmega 1280 chipset under board in the tools menu, 2 you must set the programmer to Arduino as ISP in the tools menu.

3) You must use Arduino 1.0.4
http://downloads.arduino.cc/arduino-1.0.4-windows.zip
If you use any other version the firmware will not work.

OK
Download the firmware,
Install Arduino 1.0.4
Unzip the firmware
Open the .ino file with Arduino
In Arduino open tools select the port your printer is on.
In Arduino in tools select board and set it to Mega/ Atmega 1280
In Arduino in tools select programmer and set to Arduino as ISP
Click the check mark to test the firmware
Click the arrow left icon to upload the firmware to the board.

It will take some time for the firmware to write to the board. if it fails you probably have the actual 2560 chip on your board and should not use this firmware.

I hope this helps someone.

Update 8/14/2017
Thanks to,
Nivok56
If you are having a problem with you prints being just slightly smaller than the original file
change this in the Configuration.h file.

define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {78.74, 78.74, 2560, 105.0} // default steps per unit for Ultimaker

to

define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80.10, 80.10, 2560, 105.0} // default steps per unit for Ultimaker

Thanks to,
architect_j
for bringing this to my attention.

Thermal Protection "Optional"
{In configuration.h file}
// If you want to enable this feature for all your extruder heaters,
// uncomment the 2 defines below:

// Parameters for all extruder heaters
//#define THERMAL_RUNAWAY_PROTECTION_PERIOD 40 //in seconds
//#define THERMAL_RUNAWAY_PROTECTION_HYSTERESIS 4 // in degree Celsius

// If you want to enable this feature for your bed heater,
// uncomment the 2 defines below:

// Parameters for the bed heater
//#define THERMAL_RUNAWAY_PROTECTION_BED_PERIOD 20 //in seconds
//#define THERMAL_RUNAWAY_PROTECTION_BED_HYSTERESIS 2 // in degree Celsius

This is Day 3 of my collection of printable equations. To see the whole collection, go to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227210 For today's equation, we're moving to polar coordinates! By defining distance based on the angle, you can get beautiful symmetries in curves. The other advantage of polar coordinates is that, since theta and theta+360*n define the same rotational position, it's easy to define a curve with multiple y values for the same x value (vs. cartesian coordinates which require absolute value, square roots, or more complex methods for the same effect). For the first polar equation, I picked the simple: r = atheta, which is the simplest version of Archimede's spiral (r = atheta + b, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archimedean_spiral). In this equation a controls the distance between the spirals, while b rotates the whole curve about the central axes. Archimedean spirals are used in a number of real world applications. The one I'm most familiar with is scroll compressors, which use two interleaved spirals that rotate relative to one another to compress a fluid (there's a good gif of this on the Wikipedia page). Details:
  • units are in mm
  • a = 1/18 (to give a diameter of 100 after 5 turns)
  • Range(theta) = 5 to 1800 (starting at zero causes the thickend line to overlap on itself, which Openscad's polygon command can't handle.)
  • stl resized to make x axis = 100 mm
    • As always, I'm going to continue to post one equation per day until get bored or people lose interest. If there's a particular equation you'd like to see, leave a comment and I'll give it a shot. Technical Note:
  • The thickness in the y-direction is created by plotting a second curve whose points are a constant distance in the direction perpendicular to the tangent of the first curve. This can create artifacts at regions of rapidly changing slope. However, the lower or inner curve is always correct.
All files can be printed without support. Photos shown were printed on a Replicator 2 and sliced using the standard setting on Makerware.

description.text:
This is a fuel cap for the capless diesel filler neck on the 2014 RAM 3500.  It's an exact replica of the cheap plastic one that comes on the truck from the factory (you can see it in the photos for comparison) but sometimes the dealer will throw them out or they might get lost.  Technically the filler neck doesn't need a cap (it's meant to be capless) but some people like to leave the little plastic cap on there to prevent sand or snow from getting in the filler neck (even though the fuel door itself has a rubber seal to prevent such things).  
WARNING: I have no idea if ABS or PLA or whatever-your-3D-printer-uses is safe around diesel/gasoline.  If you print one you should test it by letting it soak in some fuel for a while before actually using it.  I'd hate for it to dissolve and get in your fuel tank if you accidently splash some fuel on it.  USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!

Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2X with just one extruder with Makerbot Dark Sanguine Red.  Printed with the "Standard" profile in Makerware with 100 shells (so the entire thing is made of circles) and 120 degree build plate (in my 2X I get the best results when printing directly on the kapton tape at 120 degrees).  Printed without rafts or supports (which is why the top lip isn't perfectly smooth - there were no supports underneath when it was printed - I'm amazed it even worked! :))

print_settings.Notes:: This is a really simple design, great for learning the most basic OpenSCAD commands.

description.text:
Ever had a little bit of shampoo/conditioner left over that the pump won't reach? How about Ketchup or Mustard that won't drain out of the old bottle? What about other viscous liquids. Here's the solution. Place this device on the "new" bottle that has enough space at the top,
and invert the old bottle on top. It should now sit on a table until all the contents have transferred from the bottle on top to the one below.

To make one specific to your bottles:
Measure the Diameter of the mouth (inside/outside) and the height of the threads. Enter the
radius of the diameters and adjust the Model, render, export STL, generate code (slic3r), print.

The example STL file is for a Large shampoo/conditioner bottle.

This is a very simple OpenSCAD model, 20 lines of code, 46Line including all comments.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35mm/layer .4mm nozzle

Infill:

n/a

Notes:

This is a really simple design, great for learning the most basic OpenSCAD commands.
Removing the part is really simple because you can squeeze it to flex the sides and easily break it loose from the stage.

Concept:

The idea is to create a simple profile shape and extrude around the Z axis to create the object.

In order to see the shape as I develop the profile, I display it off-set on the Z axis.

As I add points to the shape, I save periodically to see my progress.

Start with the parameters your likely to change from version to version.

Establish the display with an offset, that you'll adjust as you go.

Establish the rotation for the object.
Note: This illustrates a non-intuitive aspect of the rotate_extrude command which is that it doesn't simply extrude from the initial position, but it first rotates your polygon around the x-axis 90 degrees, then starts the extrusion.

Enter the points of the profile polygon.

Remember it's easy to comment out sections or change how much you extrude to help in visualizing your part as you progress.

Graphing/Plotting Background:
The OpenSCAD software package is an amazing tool for showing polygons, and manipulating them. It's extraordinarily simple to learn, and allows a simple sort of introduction to programming. You are "programming shapes" and introducing some programming syntax. Displaying a polygon is one line as simple as:
polygon( points=[[0,0],[2,1],[1,2],[1,3],[3,4],[0,5]] ); It's easy to save and build on previous work. Application:
Plotting the Polygon using coordinates on the X/Y plane, Taking a 2 dimensional object and rotating it to the X/Z plane and extruding around the Z axis. Also translation within a plane is demonstrated.

Start drawing by selecting coordinates to create a polygon.
Display only the polygon. Introduce the variable: "shape" as a set of coordinates. Draw the polygon from the "shape" variable. Translate the polygon away from the Z axis Draw a second polygon from the "shape" variable. Extrude the shape (linear extrude) Change linear extrude to rotate_extrude. Offset object prior to extrude to demonstrate change in radius.

The software used is OpenSCAD, freely available from http://www.openscad.org.
Note: that if you want to rotate_extrude less than a full 360degrees, you need version 2016.x.x or newer. Older version always extrude 360 degrees.

• plotting
  • graphing
  • extruding
  • translation
45 minutes
Student will need a computer with OpenSCAD software loaded.  And a space to save their program. Programs are very short and easily printed as text or e-mailed.
The Manual for OpenSCAD is "online" at https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual
